To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cement and whitewash in order to increase his stock

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is 34 years old and married with one child.  He does construction work to earn a living. He has been in this business for seven years. He invested his money from construction work to open up a beauty shop.  Edward also practices mixed farming to earn extra income.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya in a group called Progressive, he has been motivated to work hard on his business.  

He has been able to take out a loan because his group members guaranteed him.  He got a construction contract and he is required to buy construction materials and pay his laborers.  For this reason, he has requested a loan of 60,000 KES from Faulu Kenya.  He hopes to have a fully established construction company so as to create employment for the jobless in his community.

loans.use: To buy building materials and pay his workers

loans.name: Sles

texts.en:
Mrs. F. is an older woman, 72 years old, and lives in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She is jobless and stays at home to do housework. She is married but her husband died of senility years ago. She has a financial earner in her son who drives a motor taxi (Tuk Tuk), and who is now married and lives in the family home. 

The family relies on the income from the taxi service. Unfortunately, the taxi broke down when picking up a passenger and their daily revenue has been affected. To avoid the problem, F. decided to borrow the money from Kiva’s project partner, HKL, in the amount of $800 for her son to replace his old taxi. (Mrs. F. was busy when the photo was taken so her son is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To replace his old taxi.

loans.name: Agripina

texts.en:
Even before Agripina J. became a member of ASHI in 2008, she realized that she needed to have her own small business despite her age (73 years old) so that she could help her six children support her many grandchildren. With this goal in mind, she established a small “sari-sari” (or variety) store in which she sells various types of food, beverages, and other basic commodities. She also has able to buy a piglet which she will raise and sell in four months. These businesses are possible because of Agripina’s membership in ASHI and the help she has been receiving. Her husband’s small pension would not have allowed her to help her family, but the small revenue her businesses makes allows her to provide this support.

Agripina is happy to provide this help, gets a good deal of satisfaction from managing her own store, and hopes to increase the number of items she has to sell so that she can gain more costumers and more revenues. To reach this goal, she has applied to ASHI for a new loan to grown her business and and help it bring greater happiness to the entire family.

loans.use: To buy new items to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en:
Mrs. Heang N. is 36 years-old. She sells different types of fritters from her store at her home. She sells to people who are her nearby neighbors and usually generates about $1 each day. She was busy at her business activity when the photo taken so her husband is pictured instead.  Heang N. now has four children who attend school or go to work. She also helps her life partner husband, who works in construction, earning $6.50 a day.

Heang N. lives in a very old house that is needs frequent repairs and the family’s living situation has not been comfortable. Therefore, Heang N. is applying for a loan of $1100 to repair her old house and as she intends to use some of the loan to increase her business capital.

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Twende Mbele Group

texts.fr:
Kabuo T. J. est présidente du groupe de crédit  Twende Mbele, elle lève sa main sur la photo,âgée de 37 ans, mariée, mère de 5 enfants, tous  vont à l’école. Son mari est petit commerçant, il a une pharmacie installée à Butembo, ville commerciale située dans le territoire de Lubero à plus de 410 km de Goma.
Kabuo T. J. vend des souliers usagers dans le marché central de Virunga, elle a commencé son petit commerce  avec  son fonds propre reçu de son mari  après l’éruption du volcan Nyiragongo du 16  au 17 février 2002 qui a détruit complètement toute l’économie et infrastructure de base de la ville de Goma. Son capital initial était de 50$. Il y a 8 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité de vente des souliers usagers. 
Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, Kabuo T. J. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant 100 pairs de souliers usagers. Le grand défi de cette activité est que  l’écoulement de marchandise (achat de souliers) dépend de circulation de l’argent (revenu de la population). En outre la concurrence des souliers fabriqués en Ouganda/ Kampale perturbe le prix.
Dans l’avenir, Kabuo T. J. planifie renforcer son business, augmente son compte dépôt auprès de l’IMF Hekima enfin d’accéder à un montant plus élevé de crédit au prorata de ses épargnes.
Dans le 10 ans, elle ambitionne devenir commerçante grossiste et non plus petite commerçante détaillante. Elle compte s’approvisionner à la source dans le grand centre commercial soit à Kampala ou soit à Butembo.
En plus, Kabuo T. J. est locataire, elle aimerait acheter une parcelle et construire, étant donné que  son mari travaille loin d’elle, ceci lui permettra de d’amoindrir  les poids de la charge familiale. 
Kabuo T. J. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants. 
Ce groupe Twende Mbele  est  composé de 16 membres  femmes.
texts.en:
J. Kabuo T. is president of the loan group, Twende Mbele, and it is her raising her hand on the photo. She is 37 years old, married and mother to five children, all at school. Her husband is a small businessman and has a pharmacy in Butembo, a commercial town which lies in the Lubero territory, more than 410 km from Goma. J. Kabou T. sells second-hand shoes at the central market in Virunga. She began her small business with her own funds which she received from her husband after the eruption of the Nyiragongo volcano on the 16th - 17th February 2002, which completely destroyed the economy and basic infrastructure of Goma. Her initial capital was just $50. She has been carrying out her second-hand shoe selling business for the past eight years. With the loan from IMF Hekima, J. would like to increase her turnover by buying 100 pairs of second-hand shoes. The big challenge in this business is that the flow of goods (the purchase of shoes) depends on the circulation of money (people's income). Furthermore, the competition of shoes made in Uganda/Kampala agitates the price. In the future J. plans to strengthen her business, increase the level of her deposit account with IMF Hekima and finally to access a more significant loan in proportion to her savings. In the coming ten years her ambition is to become a large wholesale businesswoman rather than a small retail businesswoman. She is planning on getting her supplies at source in the large commercial centre either in Kampala or in Butembo. Furthermore, J. Kabou T. rents her home and would like to buy a piece of land and build a house. Given that her husband works far away from her, this would allow her to reduce the burden of the family expenses. J. is grateful to IMF Hekima for the loans which she receives without any material guarantee, since thanks to these loans, she will be able to provide for the needs of her children. The Twende Mbele group is made up of 16 female members.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 100 pairs of shoes

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Bonface

texts.en: Bonface N. N. is 33 years old, single and runs a business located at Ziwani, a residential area in the town of Thika, Kenya. This region is best known for the production of pineapples, and for the last year he has made a living selling detergents, soft drinks, candles and others items to people in his area. He says that business is profitable and the only problem he has is lack of enough stock. To help solve this problem, he has applied for a loan of Kes 30,000 to restock and expand his store. He hopes to get married and have children some day, and also to go into business as a wholesaler. He is very hardworking, ambitious and well-liked.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell

loans.name: Sieng

texts.en:
To earn a living, Mrs. Sieng P., 41, sells palm sugar in the market. She gets palm juice from her husband and boils it down to sugar for sale. She is married with six children, all of whom are unmarried and almost all are employed in the garment industry. Her husband is a palm climber who taps palm juice for her to boil. 

Sieng P. finds it hard traveling because she has no a vehicle. Therefore, she is asking for a loan to add to her small savings in order to buy a used motorcycle to provide transportation for the family.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle.

loans.name: Solina

texts.en:
Now that all of Solina N.’s children are grown and have their own families to support, she and her husband have to work hard to earn enough money to meet their needs. Solina also wants to put money aside in case she or her husband needs hospitalization, medication or has other unexpected needs. Rather than depending on her husband’s sporadic and small income as a farm laborer, Solina wants to establish a business raising livestock, and has applied for a loan from ASHI to make this possible. She wants to raise these animals in their large backyard, which is covered with green grass and surrounded by the rice fields. She will sell the animals in her town's public market.

Solina hopes that someday her business will be stable and profitable enough to improve her economic status and standard of living.

loans.use: To buy livestock to raise and sell.

loans.name: Kang

texts.en:
Mrs. C., 30, lives in the rural area of Phnom Penh city. Her husband operates a motorcycle sale trade, and they have three school-aged children. 

Mrs. C. earns a living as a farmer by planting rice and vegetable crops. In addition to her farming business, C. is also a rice trader who orders rice in bulk for her stock. Since Mrs. C. lacks capital, she is pursuing a loan in order to buy mature rice to store for a while and then sell to earn income.

loans.use: To buy rice.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion enjoys being a member of ASHI and is grateful for the help this organization and its members provide. She benefits from hearing about the experiences of her fellow members and also appreciates having access to loans which allow her to run her own sari-sari (or variety) store. She is committed to meet the needs of her store's customers, and also enjoys the personal development which comes with running a business. She has applied for a loan for 20,000 PHP to buy new items to sell in her store, including rice, beverages, oil, sugar, condensed milk and other items.

Concepcion is hopeful that her business will grow into full-fledged mini-market and that she will be able to save for the future and for emergencies, since she and her husband are getting older. Their children are all grown and have their own families, and Concepcion is determined not to ask them for help. Her route for achieving this goal is expanding her store. Her dream is to earn enough money to send all of her grandchildren to college so they can find good jobs.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Ganbold

texts.en: Ganbold is 26 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a ger. His 2-year-old daughter, Anujin, attends a local kindergarten. Ganbold currently operates a clothing sales business at Narantuul market, the largest and most crowded market in the city. He purchases a variety of products from Ereen, a Chinese border city, and resells them for a profit. He started his business in 2001 with working capital of 200,000 tugrug (~ 146 USD) and has expanded his business and built a loyal customer base. Recently, in 2008, Ganbold and his wife purchased their own plot of land. They have been planning to build a house with a yard on their own land and buy new car. Ganbold is a very hardworking person. He is requesting a loan to increase his working capital.

loans.use: To increase working capital for his retail clothing buiness

loans.name: Mean

texts.en:
Mrs. Mean S., 32, has been planting a variety of crops on farmland she owns and typically earns around US $1 per day. She lives in a commune in Phnom Penh, the capital, with her husband and their four children, who go to school or work. Her husband, Theap Lor, 31, is working in the construction field. 

To increase her family's income, Mean S. hopes to invest in a pig-raising business. She has already built a pigpen, but she lacks money to buy piglets for her stall. Therefore, she would like a loan in order to purchase piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase piglets.

loans.name: Guali

texts.en:
Guali E. is a 50-year-old married man who supports his family by engaging in buy and sell of bananas, livestock and farming businesses. He lives in Brgy Bienavista, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental with his 51-year-old wife Delvith, who helps him run the business, and their five children. The children are between 9 and 29 years old. Three of the children attend school and the rest are employed so they can help the family.

He has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved their living conditions with the help of his loans from NWTF and through his own efforts. By working hard in his buy and sell banana, livestock and farming business, he is gradually making his family more economically stable. He now earns an average monthly income of PHP 20,000.

Guali is now borrowing PHP 11,000 so that he can continue his buy and sell business. This will be his sixth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. His previous loan of PHP 8,000, which he paid off well within its term, was just another step in his journey towards economic freedom. Guali aspires to elevate his family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additonal working capital

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita B., 31 years old, has spent her whole life as a farmer. She tills a small rice field and labors so hard to be able to ensure a quality harvest.

Anita has five children: her eldest is 8 years old while her youngest is only two years old. She works to support the education and other basic needs of her five children; the income she earns from her business goes directly towards the education of her children.

Anita would like to obtain a loan of Php 6,000. The loan will be utilized to buy farm supplies to achieve a better harvest on her farm.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
At her young age (36 years old), Ruth B. has become a successful businesswoman. She started her business using the loan she received from ASHI. This was just small then but because of so many trials in life, Ruth strived hard to make it grow and expand. 

Ruth feels glad about her business achievement. However, it is not yet stable enough for her to feel financially secure. Without a loan, her business can never grow. Therefore, Ruth is requesting another loan in a larger amount to support and maintain her primary business (E-Load business) and secondary business of buy and sell ventures. She hopes that by having several businesses, she will have more income, have more savings for the future of her children, and will be able to help her other relatives by employing them to work with her in her businesses.

Her vision of giving her three children a better future using the proceeds of her business enhanced her eagerness to explore the potentials of her businesses. Her husband, George has been so supportive of all her ventures.

Ruth hopes with God’s guidance that she can comply with her loan obligation and give a decent life to her family. Her long-term goal is to have her own jewelry shop, to secure a stable source of additional income, and to be financially independent from her parents. Instead of depending on her parents for some of their family expenses, she will be the one to give them financial help. Ruth will use the profits to give a better education to her three children and save some of it to support and fulfill her business dreams.

loans.use: To maintain her E-loading business and her buy and sell ventures

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Edelyn

texts.en:
38-year-old Edelyn A.’ intention for joining ASHI is to sustain her small fish-selling business by supporting her husband’s fishing activity. Revenue from her business is her family’s financial source for supporting their daily needs. Edelyn has three children to support and attend to. While they are still young (they are between 7 and 13 years old), she wants to put up a savings fund for their future education in college.

Through ASHI, Edelyn is requesting a loan to purchase a small fishing boat that will be operated manually by her husband. In her mind, once her husband has his own fishing boat, he can go fishing as often as he wants, rather than just borrowing a fishing boat from a neighbor or joining others in fishing in which case he would only receive a small share of the catch. 

Since Edelyn now has access to a loan, she hopes that her family’s standard of living will improve.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat.

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda G. is a 60 year old widow who supports her family by selling fish and oysters. She lives in Catali Barangay Daan Banua, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their 6 children. The children are between the ages of 27 and 38 years old, some of them already have their own families. 

Florenda has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business, selling fish and oysters, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000.

Florenda is now borrowing PHP 17,000 so that she can continue her business of selling of fish and oysters. This will be her 12th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Florenda aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
Edgar Y., 37 years old, is a farmer. He said that his farming helps a lot to sustain all his family needs. He started his business in 2001.

Edgar has two children and his eldest child is seven years old. He dreams of providing for the needs of his family. That is why, today, he is starting to save money to become financially ready when his children study in college.

Edgar would like to obtain a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy farm supplies to improve his harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna P. is a member of a Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI) cluster organization. She attends monthly meetings and has obtained loan services from CEVI.

Edna’s business is rice production. She tills only a small farm but her income goes directly towards the needs of her family and children. Because she wanted to augment her income, she also ventured into a piggery business. Now, she is earning with the pigs, too.

Edna would like to request a loan of Php 6,000. She will utilize her loan to buy farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Ecelia

texts.en:
Ecelia P. runs a small piggery. Aside from pigs, she also maintains a small rice field in Banga, South Cotabato. She has applied for a loan to be able to support the needs of her business such as piglets, feed and labor.

Ecelia has three children and her eldest child is 22. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. which she will use to buy farm supplies and piglets.

Ecelia chose CEVI because it has micro-insurance coverage on her as a client and on her family members.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies, piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Efren

texts.en:
Efren L. lives in Banga, South Cotabato. He is 59 years old and has three children.

Efren has only a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farm but the income he gets from growing rice benefits all his children and grandchildren. He has spent his whole life as a farmer. He dreams that someday he will have bigger farm.

Efren would like to obtain a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy additional farm supplies to increase his harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and food to sell.

loans.name: Flordeliz

texts.en:
Flordeliz R., 28 years old, is a farmer from Banga, South Cotabato. She has two children: one is 2 years old while the other one is 4 months old.

Flordeliz has a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farm and she grows corn on it. The last time she harvested her crop, she said, she got eighty-five sacks of corn. The income of her business helps a lot in buying the daily needs of her family.

Flordeliz would like to obtain a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to increase her harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn T., 42 years old, is a corn and rice farmer. She started farming in 1993.

Jocelyn has two children and her eldest child is 16 years old. Her income goes directly to her children. She labors so hard so that she will be able to buy food, clothing and other basic needs for her family.

Jocelyn is requesting a loan of Php 6,000. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies so that she will have a better harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the financial capital of her fish-selling business

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose N., 54 years old, invests so much in his piggery business. It was in 1983 that he started growing pigs and, until now, he is still doing the same thing since it is a very profitable business. Jose has five children. His eldest child is 31 years old and unmarried.

Jose would like to request a loan of Php 6,000. He will use the loan to buy piglets for his piggery and farm supplies to increase his harvest. Jose chose CEVI because he likes the micro-insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy piglets and farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more yams, potatoes, beans and frozen food to sell.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly S. is a 47-year old married woman who lives in Bulwang, Mabinay, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by her general store and welding shop business.

Nelly’s 48 year old husband, Marcos, manages their welding shop business. They have 2 children who are between 22 and 25 years old. One child is currently going to school and also helps out in the business as part of their daily chores, while their other child has their own family.

Nelly joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 in the hopes that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in the general store and a welding shop business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 9,000 from her business activities.

Nelly is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 was used to fund operations of her general store and welding shop, which had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing, for her 15th cycle loan, the amount of PHP 19,500, which she intends to use towards her general store and welding shop business again. Nelly is working hard to achieve the dreams and aspirations that she has for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additonal working capital.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna J. is a 50 year old married woman who supports her family through her general store and retail banana business. She lives in Barangay Tagbino, Vallehermoso, Negros Oriental with her 45 year old husband, Cerelo, who is a government employee. Their 2 children, who are between 12 and 19 years old, also live with them and are currently going to school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and banana retail business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 24,000.

Lorna is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can expand her general store and banana retail business. This will be her 17th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 13,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Lorna aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida B., 54 years old, is a farmer. She has one child who is 16 years old and works so hard to be able to support her child’s needs. The income, which she gets from growing rice, has helped her family a lot to buy food and other basic needs.

Now, Leonida has a little problem in financing her rice farm and that is why she needs to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more motorcycle spare parts to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 24 years old. She is married has a one child. She graduated from primary school. 

She is a seamstress and has been working in this field for more than four years. She wants a loan to purchase a sewing machine and cloth. All her customers are female and she is a very skilled and experienced woman. Her sewing is so nice and attractive that most of the ladies of the district come to her. She has a good reputation in the market and her prices are reasonable and cheap.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and cloth

loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en: Mrs. Chhuon S., 38, is a divorced mother of five children; one is employed as a machinery repairman and the other four are students who also assist their mother’s business when they are free.  Chhuon is a local farmer who plants rice and vegetables on the land that she inherited from her parents, but with the farming season approaching, she doesn’t have enough materials to supply her field, so she is looking for a loan to buy fertilizer and crop seeds. She proposes to use the other half of the loan to buy an old motorcycle for riding needs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and crops seed for growing.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en: Having five children, 38 years old Marilou D. O. doesn’t know anymore how will she budget their small income. Her husband works as a farmer and she is helping him maintain the rice field. She is currently preparing her farm for planting and needs help to be able improve their harvest and so is applying for a loan of Php 6,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Adelyn

texts.en: Adelyn, 26, is a rice farmer and mother of a three-year-old child in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Her business is a big help to her family, as It is there where they get the food they eat everyday and also how they can pay the amount borrowed from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. Adelyn also sells dried fish for additional capital.  She currently lacks the capital to provide all the farm supplies needed for her farm and so is requesting a loan of 15,000 Php  from CEVI, a loan that will really help her business venture.

loans.use: Farm supplies and dried fish

loans.name: Nike

texts.en:
Nike sells groceries, drinks and medicines to her retail costumers and she has been in this business for the past six years. She is 47 years of age and she has three children. Her husband is a mechanical engineer and they live in Lagos.

Nike is very happy about her business and she wishes to expand it. She hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more medicines, groceries and drinks to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines, groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en: Merlyn D.  a 50-year-old farmer from Banga South Cotabato, has four children, her eldest 22 years old. Merlyn has a farm which she hopes can provide for the daily needs of her family. Because she wants to make her livelihood more profitable in order to improve the family's economic situation, she is applying for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Remy

texts.en: Remy Balderino, a 34-year-old rice farmer, has three children. Currently, he tills a 1-hectare farm. The income of his business goes directly towards his family. He would like to grow his rice farm business and has been busy preparing it for the next planting. However, he still needs additional money to complete the process. He thought of applying for a loan of Php 6,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en: In Sto. Niño, South Cotabato, Angelita owns a sari-sari store and a rice field, businesses she started in 2008. Until she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., she found it hard to look for additional capital for her businesses. She is now requesting a loan of 15,000 Php in order to buy more groceries for her store as well as farm supplies. This will be helpful to Angelita since she has three children who need support.

loans.use: Farm supplies and groceries

loans.name: Rhonalyn

texts.en: Rhonalyn M., 32 years old, is a rice grower who manages her farm alone and desires an abundant harvest. Her parents taught her everything about farming, and she wants to make her enterprise productive to support the needs of her only child.  Rhonalyn would like to apply a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies and fertilizer

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en: Bernard, a 45-year-old married father of two, is a carpenter of 17 years' experience with two employees.  His wife is employed as a teacher.  Bernard joined a group in Faulu Kenya so that he could easily access loans.  He previously secured a loan of Kes. 25,000 to buy a plot of land and is now requesting a loan of Kes. 50,000 to buy timber. Describing himself as a focused man, Bernard hopes to own several workshops in the future.

loans.use: To buy timber

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 24 years old. He is married and has one child. He graduated from primary school. 

He sells electrical supplies. He will use the loan funds to purchase electric materials such as, wires, cables, and lamps. He has been working in this field for a long time and has acquired a great deal of experience and expertise. He has enough customers because of the good quality of his work. His income will rise because of this loan and could change his life because he has a strong desire to succeed and is serious about his job.

loans.use: Cables, wires, and lamps

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and food to sell.

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
Belen is an entrepreneur who does business in rice and pig farming. She manages a rice field and a piggery. She said that her business is going well because of the help of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She’s been a member of CEVI since 2008. 

She is currently asking for a loan of 15,000 Philippine Pesos to continually support her business. She supports 7 children in her family. She is determined to do her best in providing for the needs of her family.

loans.use: farm supplies and pig feed

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en: Rosalie B., 41 years old, is a pig grower. She has two children; the eldest is 18. She works very hard so that she can provide her family's needs. She started her piggery in 1990. Up to now, she has been growing pigs because for her it is a profitable business to be in.  Aside from pigs, she also maintains a 1-hectare farm. She grows rice. Her rice farm supplements the family income. She would like to request a loan of 6,000 Philippine Pesos. She will use the loan to buy piglets and feed.

loans.use: Piglets and feed

loans.name: Eilleen

texts.en: Eilleen’s family is sustained by pig farming and canteen vending. She is 44 years old and from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. In 2000 she started these businesses. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to back up her business with additional capital. She requested 15,000 Philippine Pesos to buy food ingredients and feed for pigs.

loans.use: pig feed and food ingredients

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sugar, cooking fat and maize flour

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase motorcycle spare parts.

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en: Sharon Y. is 26 years old and lives in Banga South Cotabato. She is a farmer. Her main crop is rice. She has a 1-hectare farm. She works very hard to ensure an abundant harvest. She has one child, who is 9 years old. She started planting rice last 2009. She is requesting a loan of 6,000 Philippine Pesos from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to grow her harvest.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more hair extensions and hair cream to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase motorcycle spare parts to sell and to improve his farm

loans.name: Ngin

texts.en: Mrs. S. grows crops on the farmland behind her house. Her husband helps with the farming as well. They earn a combined $2 per day and live with two children, who attend school. Due to rising family expenses, they must both work very hard every day to grow enough crops to support the family. S. is asking for a loan of $100 to support her farming business.

loans.use: To support her farming business.

loans.name: Enelyn

texts.en:
Enelyn owns a store that sells farm supplies. She also manages a rice field in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. It’s her only way of earning an income for her family. Her businesses are improving with the help of micro-finance. She requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to help finance her businesses. 

She is a mother of 2 children and wishes them to earn a degree. She’s asking for a loan of 15,000 Philippine Pesos to support her businesses.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en:
Kehinde is in the business of buying and selling yams. She sees this as her means of livelihood and has been in the business for over 18 years. She wants to increase the size of her business and its profitability. This she said can be achieved by purchasing more yams to sell. She hopes to use the loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more yams to sell.

Kehinde is 35 years of age and is married with five children. Her husband is a fashion designer and they both live in Lagos state, Nigeria. She has been a member of LAPO micro-finance for some years with a good record. She thanks all Kiva lenders and LAPO micro-finance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase yams to sell

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a hardworking man who owns a barber shop.  He has been in this business for three years.  He is 32 years old and married.  Peter works hard in his business because he is the breadwinner in his family.  He is a member of Amani group in Faulu Kenya and saves his money weekly with the group.  This has made him invest in his business.  

Peter has requested a loan of 60,000 Kenyan Shillings from Faulu Kenya to buy more shaving machines.  He believes that if he adds more machines he would provide his services efficiently.  He dreams of having a well established business in the future.

loans.use: To buy more shaving machines

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sugar, cooking fat and maize flour

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 45 years old. He is married and has two children. He graduated from high school. 

He sells spare parts and has been working in this occupation for a long time. His shop is in the industrial zone and lots of people buy from him. 

He will use this loan to purchase spare parts for large vehicles and vans. As a result of this loan, his income will rise and he will gain a lot of customers.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts

loans.name: Dropati

texts.en:
Dropati M. is a resident of Thecho, Lalitpur, and lives with her husband and three daughters. Thecho is one of the developing villages in Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in agricultural farming. Mrs. M. is a shopkeeper in Thecho, and sells pots and utensils. Along with her husband, Mahendra Majarjan, she opened her shop six years ago. The couple contribute their efforts equally in their shop because they have no other source of income. Their children also help them.
Mrs. M. is asking for loan to expand her shop by buying items, such as plates, steel cups and hotpots, to meet the increasing demands of customers. She wants to strengthen her family's economic condition by increasing her income.

loans.use: To buy kitchen goods for resale

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine V. is a religious woman and a hard-working entrepreneur who has been in business for more than 20 years. She is a married mother of three children. Her husband is a tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) driver in the community while she manages her own variety store to supply additional income for the family.  
 
Josephine would like to receive a loan as working capital to buy additional groceries for her variety store. A proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2005, Josephine has been a dedicated member regularly attending weekly center meetings and making solid repayments on previous loans.

Her long-term goals include having a full-fledged mini-groceries store. Also, she hopes that the profits from her business will fund her three children's continued education until they have completed college degrees.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Josephine is determined to achieve a winning business to build more long-term financial security for her and her family.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 40 years old. 

He is a baker. He has been working in this business for long time. He is a skilled and experienced man. 

He will use this loan to replace his old clay oven with new one and to buy a kneading machine. 

He has a good reputation in the market. His bread is fresh and flavorful and he has constant clients. People come from all districts to purchase bread from him.

loans.use: Replace an old clay oven

loans.name: Anecia

texts.en:
Anecia L. is persistent in pursuing her dream of growing her taho (sweet tofu-based snack) vending business. Despite the difficulty in maintaining her business as she cannot re-invest her business income into it as it is also the main income source for her family's daily expenses, Anecia is hopeful that some day her dream will be ground on the palm of her hand. With that, she wants to request a much larger loan to support her business's needs and at the same time to sustain its operation. With her passion for giving her children a better future and a decent kind of life, she will be willing to work hard and to help her husband’s sporadic income as a taho vendor.

As a mother, Anecia’s dreams are always for her children and family. She wants to improve her children's quality of life. In 2007, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. She hoped to have secured access to capital for the continuation of her taho vending business. Her previous loans were carefully utilized as additional and rolling capital for her business. 

Anecia is hopeful that her business will grow and that some day she will have more customers around the village. She also dreams of sending all her children to school until college and that they find good jobs. One of her aspirations is to be able to build a house that is durable and spacious.

loans.use: To support her business's needs and to sustain its operation

loans.name: Dilaluz

texts.en:
Dilaluz D., aged 65, wants to grow the small hog fattening and rice retail businesses that she has set up using the loans she has accessed through ASHI. Proceeds from these businesses are the only source of income for her family for all their needs including her medication. In addition to her 67-year-old jobless husband, Dilaluz is also supporting her children aged 31 and 33. However, one of her children is her partner in running her business. 

Despite being poor in health and financially, Dilaluz still feels happy that she has had the opportunity to receive a loan and to have a business of her own. She enjoys using its profit to support her family's needs. Some day she hopes that her business will grow so her children can take it over.

loans.use: To purchase a piglet for fattening and a large volume of rice to sell

loans.name: Nouratou L. Lydole

texts.fr: A. Nouratou L. Lydole est née le 22 Mars 1966 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à BOKOSSA Raoul, Nouratou est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Nouratou vit depuis treize ans environs à Dandji, un quartier de Cotonou, avec sa famille. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Nouratou a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis dix ans environs, Nouratou mène comme activité, la vente de tissus, chaussures et des bijoux dans sa boutique située à son domicile. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l’aidant à assurer à ses enfants, un bon train de vie. Nouratou achète ses articles à Lomé au Togo et aussi au Nigeria, États voisins du Bénin. Nouratou est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a bien remboursé tous les crédits qu’elle a obtenus antérieurement de ALIDé. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Nouratou désire renforcer son activité et reconstituer son stock de produits, en vue de mieux faire face aux exigences de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
A. Nouratou L. Lydole was born on the 22nd of March, 1966 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Raoul Bokossa and is a mother of three school-aged children. Nouratou has lived with her family in Dandji, a district in Cotonou, for around 13 years, and the couple see to the family's needs together. Nouratou left school at secondary level and for the past 10 years has sold fabric, shoes and jewellery from her home-run shop. This business activity generates revenues that allow her to look after her children's living conditions. Nouratou buys her items from Lomé in Togo, and from Nigeria, Benin's neighbouring states. Nouratou is an old ALIDé client who successfully repaid all the loans that she received in the past from ALIDé. Given her customers' mounting demands, Nouratou wishes to boost her business by enlarging her product range.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric, jewellery and shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell

loans.name: A. Reine

texts.fr: Née en 1969 à Dangbo dans le département de l’Ouémé au Bénin, G. A. Reine s’est installée à Tchonvi dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis cinq ans.  Reine habite seule avec ses trois enfants, et assure seule leurs différentes charges. Reine est une veuve et n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Pour assurer ses différents besoins, Reine exerce comme activité, la vente de sacs de riz et de l’huile d'arachide, à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Reine s’approvisionne à Gbogbanou, un marché du Bénin. Reine exerce cette activité depuis dix ans, et a déjà obtenu deux prêts qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Dans l’optique de renforcer son activité et d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire, et donc sa clientèle, Reine sollicite un troisième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1969 in Dangbo, in Ouémé County, Benin, Ms. G. A. Reine settled in Tchonvi, in the community of Sèmè-Podji, five years ago. She lives alone with her three children, and by herself she ensures that their various expenses are covered. Reine is a widow and attended primary school only. To meet her different needs, she has a business selling sacks of rice and peanut oil at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She gets her supplies in Gbogbanou, a market in Benin. She has been in this business for ten years and has already had two loans, which she has repaid. With regard to bolstering her business and increasing her sales, and thus her customer base, Reine is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of rice in bulk

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea R. is a strong 49-year-old woman with the determination and faith to get out from the ties of poverty. She is the mother of three children. As a mother with big dreams, in 2006, she joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), a micro-finance institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since then, Andrea started selling rice and direct selling Avon products and this really helped to meet their needs. 

Now on her sixth loan, she proposes to use the loan amount of 28,000 pesos to purchase more inventory for her business. Specifically, the loan funds will be used to pay for 16 sacks of rice and to purchase Avon products. She hopes that, with the help of ASHI as a KIVA field partner, she can reach her ambition to step out from poverty, expand her business and pay for her three children's needs in school until they complete college degrees.

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice and Avon products

loans.name: Liliane

texts.fr: S. Liliane est née en 1973 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à MIWAKOUNOU Moïse, Liliane est mère de cinq enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Liliane vit avec ses enfants et son mari à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. C’est depuis huit ans environs que Liliane vit dans ce quartier. Liliane n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis six ans environs, Liliane vend divers produits (biscuits, savons, huile, cahier, farine de manioc, riz, etc.) à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Liliane achète ses produits. Liliane est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu quatre prêts qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Liliane désire augmenter davantage le stock de ses produits et accroître sa part de marché ; raison pour laquelle Liliane  sollicite un autre prêt.
texts.en:
Liliane S. was born in Cotonou in 1973, Benin's economic capital. She is married to Moïse Miwakounou and they have five children. A few of the children attend school. Liliane lives with her husband and her children in Agblangandan in the village Sèmè-Podji. She has lived there for eight years. Liliane never went to school. However, for six years, she has been selling a variety of products (cookies, soaps, oil, notebooks, manioc flour, rice etc.) from her home. Liliane buys her products in the international market in Dantokpa. She is a former client of ALID, and she has already recieved four loans that have been repayed in full. Liliane would like to stock her products and expand her sales, which is why she is applying for another loan.

Translated from French by Kristin Connor, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of products (pastas, cookies, soaps, manioc flour, oil etc.)

loans.name: Tuungane Group

texts.fr:
Kavira B. J. est présidente du groupe de crédit  Tuungane, elle lève sa main sur la photo,  âgée de 48 ans, veuve, mère de 5 enfants, parmi les quels 3 ont leurs propres foyers et 2 étudient. Son mari est décédé, il y a 2 ans suite à une longue maladie. Pendant tout ce temps, elle supporte seule la charge de ses enfants orphelins.
Kavira B. J. vend en gros des poissons fumés et frais  au marché central de Virunga, elle a  commencé son petit commerce  avec  son fonds propre, gain  de 100$ (profit) d’une petite commission. A ce moment là, elle vivait encore à Vitshumbi, pêcherie située au long  du lac (cote Ouest du lac Virunga) anciennement appelé lac Edouard. Elle fut commissionnaire, intermédiaire, facilitateur entre les acheteurs des poissons en provenance de la ville de Bukavu (sud Kivu) et les pêcheurs exploitants de Vitshumbi. Il y a 22 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité de vente des poissons. 
Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, Kavira B. J. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant 200 poissons environs 2 paniers des poissons fumés et 400 poissons frais environs 3 paniers. Le grand défi de cette activité est la perte due à la pourriture des boissons. Sur ce, elle compte acheter un congélateur (frigo). Pour sa famille, Kavira B. J. souhaite scolariser régulièrement ses enfants orphelins et les voir obtenir leurs diplômes pour qu’ils soient utiles à eux-mêmes et pour la société.
Dans l’avenir, Kavira B. J. planifie construire une maison  de 4 chambres dans sa parcelle, qu’elle mettra à location pour  augmenter son revenu.
Kavira B. J. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants. 
Ce groupe Tuungane  est  composé de 14 membres  femmes.
texts.en:
Kavira B. J. is president of the Tuungane loan group, and it is her raising her hand on the photo. She is a 48-year old widow and mother to five children, three of whom have their own homes and two who are students. Her husband passed away two years ago after a long illness. During all this time she has been the sole provider for her fatherless children. Kavira sells smoked and fresh fish on a wholesale basis at the central market in Virunga. She began her small business with her own funds, a profit of $100 from a small commission. At that time she still lived in Vitshumbi, a fishing village situated alongside the west coast of Lake Verunga (known previously as Lake Edouard). She was delivery girl, intermediary and assistant to fish buyers coming from the town of Bukavi (south Kivu) and the fish farmers in Vitshumbi. She has been carrying out this fish selling business for the past 22 years. With the loan from IMF Hekima, Kavira would like to increase her turnover by buying 200 or approximately two baskets of smoked fish and 400 or approximately three baskets of fresh fish. The main challenge of this activity is not to lose fish as a result of them rotting. For this reason she would like to buy a freezer. As far as her family is concerned, Kavira would like to send her fatherless children to school on a regular basis and see them get their diplomas so that they can do something useful for themselves and for society. In the future, Kavira is planning to build a house with four bedrooms on her patch of land, which she will rent out in order to increase her income. Kavira is grateful to IMF Hekima for her loans which she obtains without any material guarantee, since thanks to these loans she is able to provide for the needs of her children. The Tuungane group is made up of 14 female members.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 200 smoked fish and 400 fresh fish

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy sells groceries and also makes beads to sell in her shop: she has been in this business for the past 14 years. She is 45 years old, married with four children. She lives in Lagos state. 

Mercy is very focused and hardworking. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 120,000 to purchase more groceries and beads to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase groceries and beads to sell

loans.name: Raïmatou M.

texts.fr: F. Raïmatou M. est née le 10 Décembre 1975 à Sakété, dans le département du Plateau au Bénin. Raïmatou est mariée à OSSENI Latifou, un maçon. Le couple a trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés Raïmatou supporte avec son mari, les différentes charges familiales. La famille vit depuis six ans à Sèkandji, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Raïmatou n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Depuis quinze ans, Raïmatou mène comme activité, la vente de friperies à Sèkandji. Raïmatou achète ses produits à Dantkpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé au Togo. Raïmatou a déjà obtenu deux prêts qu’elle avait tous bien remboursés. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité et de mieux faire face aux différents exigences de sa clientèle, Raïmatou sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Raïmatou M F. was born December 10, 1975 in Sakété in the district of Plateau au Bénin. Raïmatou is married to Latifou Osseni, a mason. The couple has three children who all attend school. Raïmatou shares household duties with her husband. The family has lived in Sèkandji for 6 years in the village of Sèmè-Podji. Raïmatou never went to school, but for 15 years, she has sold second hand clothes in Sèkandji. Raïmatou buys her products in Dantkpa, an international market in Benin. She also buys her products in Lomé in Togo. Raïmatou has already received and repayed 10 loans. With the goal of expanding her activity and to better meet clients' demands, Raïmatou is seeking a third credit through ALIDé.

Translated from French by Kristin Connor, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase second hand clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more bags of cement to sell

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.en:
Dilshod is a young married man who raises livestock to help his parents with their expenses and to save to build his own house in the future. This isn't an unpleasant occupation for him, actually it is quite the contrary. Dilshod carries out his duties with an enormous pleasure and with great affection towards the animals, taking care of them in the best way possible. Like every young person, he has dreams that he longs to see materialize. One of them is to add to his livestock herd so that, with time, he will be able to sell them in the market, especially on holidays. Dilshod is requesting a loan for this reason. He wishes to purchase cattle to add to his herd of animals and to increase his income by the year's end.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Anvarali

texts.en:
J. Anvarali is 30 years old. He is married and has two children. For 5 years Anvarali has been running a farming business and also providing the service of a tractor driver to local farmers. He is planning to sow potatoes and onions on his land. He wants to borrow the loan for purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer for processing the land. Therefore, Anvarali is asking for a loan of 5500 Somoni. You could become an important part in Anvarali family's life, and he deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fuel and lubricants, and supplies to redo the cattle-shed.

loans.name: Mukarram

texts.en:
Mukarram J. is 52 years old. She lives with her husband and their two children, for whom she works every day so that they can fulfill their goals in life. She operates a business growing and selling vegetables like potatoes, onions, and carrots. Thanks to help from her husband and their children, as well as her own dedication and persistence, the business has grown considerably, from uncultivated land to a whole big garden. Now Mukarram is  requesting 5400 Somoni. She will buy fertilizer and prepare her garden for the upcoming season so that she can provide the quality of produce that her customers expect. Let’s help this mother to keep working for the wellbeing of her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.
